backstory: Bernard Arnault, born in 1949 in Roubaix, France, is the chairman and CEO of LVMH, the world's largest luxury goods company. Known for his keen business acumen, Arnault began his career by taking over his father's construction business, Ferret-Savinel, in 1971. After restructuring the company and selling off its non-core assets, he entered the luxury market in 1984 by acquiring the nearly bankrupt textile company Boussac, which owned the prestigious brand Christian Dior. This move marked the beginning of Arnault's journey into the luxury industry. Over the years, he transformed LVMH into a global powerhouse by acquiring iconic brands like Louis Vuitton, Moët & Chandon, and Sephora. His success stems from his ability to blend heritage and innovation, making LVMH a symbol of modern luxury. Today, Arnault is not only one of the wealthiest individuals in the world but also a prominent art collector and philanthropist.

Elon Musk, born in Pretoria, South Africa, in 1971, is an entrepreneur, inventor, and visionary known for founding companies like Tesla, SpaceX, Neuralink, and The Boring Company. From a young age, Musk showed an interest in technology and innovation. He taught himself computer programming at the age of 10 and created his first software, a game called Blastar, by the age of 12. After moving to the United States, Musk attended the University of Pennsylvania, where he studied physics and economics. He co-founded Zip2, an online city guide software, which he sold for $307 million in 1999. With the proceeds, Musk founded X.com, which later became PayPal. In 2002, he founded SpaceX, aiming to reduce space transportation costs and enable the colonization of Mars. Musk's ventures are driven by his mission to accelerate humanity's transition to sustainable energy and make life multi-planetary.

Jeff Bezos, born in Albuquerque, New Mexico, in 1964, is the founder of Amazon, one of the largest e-commerce platforms in the world. After graduating from Princeton University with degrees in electrical engineering and computer science, Bezos worked on Wall Street before taking a bold step to start his own company. In 1994, he launched Amazon from his garage in Seattle, initially selling books online. Bezos's vision was to create an 'everything store,' and under his leadership, Amazon expanded into a global marketplace, offering products ranging from electronics to cloud computing services. Known for his customer-centric approach and long-term thinking, Bezos revolutionized retail and logistics. In addition to Amazon, he owns The Washington Post and Blue Origin, a space exploration company aiming to make space travel accessible to everyone.

Larry Ellison, born in 1944 in New York City, is the co-founder of Oracle Corporation, a multinational computer technology company. Raised by his aunt and uncle in Chicago, Ellison showed an early aptitude for mathematics and science but dropped out of college twice. In 1977, he founded Oracle with just $2,000, initially focusing on database software for the CIA, codenamed 'Oracle.' The company grew rapidly, becoming a leader in database management systems and enterprise software. Ellison is known for his flamboyant lifestyle, including owning a Hawaiian island and competing in yacht races. Despite his reputation for being competitive and driven, he has also made significant contributions to philanthropy, particularly in medical research. His journey from a modest upbringing to becoming one of the world's wealthiest individuals exemplifies perseverance and innovation.

Warren Buffett, born in 1930 in Omaha, Nebraska, is known as the 'Oracle of Omaha' for his investment expertise. Buffett developed an interest in business and investing at a young age, buying his first stock at the age of 11. After studying under Benjamin Graham at Columbia Business School, Buffett applied Graham's value investing principles to build his fortune. In 1965, he took control of Berkshire Hathaway, transforming it from a struggling textile company into a multinational conglomerate. Through his disciplined approach to investing, Buffett amassed one of the largest fortunes in the world. Despite his immense wealth, Buffett is known for his frugality and commitment to philanthropy, having pledged to donate the majority of his fortune to charitable causes. His annual letters to shareholders are widely regarded as insightful guides to investment and business management.

Bill Gates, born in 1955 in Seattle, Washington, is the co-founder of Microsoft Corporation. From an early age, Gates demonstrated an aptitude for technology and innovation. In 1975, he and his childhood friend Paul Allen founded Microsoft, a company that revolutionized the personal computer industry with its software innovations, particularly the Windows operating system. Gates served as CEO until 2000 and played a pivotal role in making Microsoft one of the largest and most influential tech companies in the world. Beyond his work in technology, Gates is a philanthropist, dedicating much of his wealth to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, which focuses on global health, education, and poverty alleviation.

Mark Zuckerberg, born in 1984 in White Plains, New York, is the co-founder and CEO of Meta Platforms (formerly Facebook, Inc.). While studying at Harvard University, Zuckerberg launched 'The Facebook' in 2004 as a social networking platform for college students. The platform rapidly expanded beyond universities, becoming the world's largest social media platform. Under Zuckerberg's leadership, Meta acquired companies like Instagram and WhatsApp, cementing its dominance in social media. Despite facing controversies over privacy and misinformation, Zuckerberg has focused on innovation, including the development of the metaverse. He is also involved in philanthropy through the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, which aims to address social challenges like education and healthcare.

Amancio Ortega, born in 1936 in Busdongo de Arbás, Spain, is the founder of Inditex, the world's largest fashion retailer, best known for its flagship brand, Zara. Starting his career as a shop assistant, Ortega worked his way up the fashion industry by learning about fabric production and customer preferences. In 1975, he co-founded Zara with his then-wife Rosalía Mera, introducing the concept of 'fast fashion' by bringing affordable, high-quality, and trendy clothing to customers quickly. Ortega's innovative supply chain strategies disrupted the fashion industry, allowing Inditex to expand globally. Despite his immense wealth, Ortega maintains a low profile and rarely gives interviews, preferring a simple lifestyle.

Mukesh Ambani, born in 1957 in Yemen, is the chairman and largest shareholder of Reliance Industries, India's most valuable company. After studying chemical engineering and business administration, Ambani joined Reliance, which was founded by his father, Dhirubhai Ambani. Under Mukesh's leadership, the company diversified from textiles into petrochemicals, telecommunications, and retail, becoming a cornerstone of India's economy. Ambani is credited with launching Jio, a revolutionary telecom service that disrupted the Indian market with affordable data and digital services. Despite his business achievements, Ambani is also known for his philanthropic efforts, particularly in education, healthcare, and rural development in India.

Larry Page, born in 1973 in Lansing, Michigan, is the co-founder of Google, one of the most influential companies in the world. While pursuing his Ph.D. at Stanford University, Page, along with Sergey Brin, developed the PageRank algorithm, which became the foundation of Google's search engine. In 1998, the two officially launched Google, which grew rapidly to become a leader in search, advertising, and cloud computing. As CEO of Google's parent company, Alphabet, Page focused on innovative projects like self-driving cars and artificial intelligence. Known for his visionary ideas and technical expertise, Page has significantly shaped the way people access and interact with information online.

Sergey Brin, born in 1973 in Moscow, Russia, immigrated to the United States with his family to escape anti-Semitism. Brin studied mathematics and computer science at the University of Maryland before pursuing a Ph.D. at Stanford University, where he met Larry Page. Together, they co-founded Google in 1998. Brin's focus on data mining and machine learning has helped Google become a pioneer in search and artificial intelligence. Known for his adventurous spirit, Brin has also invested in futuristic technologies like self-driving cars. He stepped down from his role at Alphabet in 2019 but remains influential in tech and philanthropy.

Alice Walton, born in 1949 in Newport, Arkansas, is the daughter of Walmart founder Sam Walton. Unlike her siblings, who focused on the retail business, Alice pursued her passion for art. She founded the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Arkansas, which houses a renowned collection of American artwork. Walton is also an advocate for education and healthcare reform. Despite her vast fortune, she maintains a low public profile and is deeply involved in philanthropic initiatives through the Walton Family Foundation.

Michael Bloomberg, born in 1942 in Boston, Massachusetts, is the founder of Bloomberg L.P., a global financial information and media company. Bloomberg began his career on Wall Street before launching his eponymous company in 1981, which revolutionized financial data with the Bloomberg Terminal. He served as the mayor of New York City from 2002 to 2013, focusing on public health and urban development. Bloomberg is also a leading philanthropist, donating billions to causes like climate change, public health, and education. His blend of business acumen and public service has made him one of the most influential figures in finance and politics.

Gautam Adani, born in 1962 in Ahmedabad, India, is the founder and chairman of the Adani Group, a multinational conglomerate with interests in ports, energy, and logistics. Adani began his career as a diamond sorter before starting his trading company in 1988. Over the decades, he has built a business empire that is instrumental in India's infrastructure development. Despite controversies over environmental issues, Adani is a key player in renewable energy and has pledged to achieve carbon neutrality for his group. His rise from modest beginnings to one of the world's richest individuals is a testament to his vision and perseverance.

Sheldon Adelson, born in 1933 in Boston, Massachusetts, was a business magnate and philanthropist who transformed the global casino industry. Adelson started his career in entrepreneurship before founding Las Vegas Sands Corporation, which operates resorts in Las Vegas, Macau, and Singapore. Known for his lavish investments, he redefined luxury tourism and gaming. Adelson was also a prominent political donor and philanthropist, supporting medical research and Jewish causes. He passed away in 2021, leaving behind a legacy of innovation and generosity.

Zhang Yiming, born in 1983 in Longyan, China, is the founder of ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, one of the world's most popular social media platforms. After studying software engineering, Zhang worked at several tech firms before founding ByteDance in 2012. The company's first product, Toutiao, was a success, but TikTok propelled ByteDance to global prominence. Known for his innovative algorithms, Zhang stepped down as CEO in 2021 but remains an influential figure in the tech industry.

David Thomson, born in 1957 in Toronto, Canada, is the chairman of Thomson Reuters, a media and financial information company. Thomson inherited his wealth from his father, who built a media empire. Under David’s leadership, the company expanded its focus on financial data and services. Thomson is also an art collector and philanthropist, supporting institutions like the Art Gallery of Ontario. Despite his vast wealth, Thomson is known for his private lifestyle.

Phil Knight, born in 1938 in Portland, Oregon, is the co-founder of Nike, the world’s leading athletic apparel company. Knight partnered with his track coach, Bill Bowerman, to create Blue Ribbon Sports, which evolved into Nike in 1971. Under Knight’s leadership, Nike became a global brand synonymous with sports and innovation. After stepping down as chairman in 2016, Knight focused on philanthropy, donating billions to education and healthcare.

Leonard Lauder, born in 1933 in New York City, is the chairman emeritus of Estée Lauder Companies, a global beauty empire. Lauder joined the family business in the 1950s, helping to expand it into one of the most recognized names in cosmetics. A passionate art collector, he donated significant works to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Lauder is also a philanthropist, supporting cancer research and education.

Stefan Persson, born in 1947 in Stockholm, Sweden, is the former chairman of H&M, one of the world’s largest fashion retailers. Persson took over the family business in the 1980s, expanding its global presence. Known for its affordable and trendy clothing, H&M thrived under his leadership. Persson stepped down in 2020, passing the company to his son. He is also a philanthropist, supporting sustainability initiatives.

Francoise Bettencourt Meyers, born in 1953 in Neuilly-sur-Seine, France, is the heiress to the L'Oréal fortune and the chairwoman of her family's holding company. As the granddaughter of L'Oréal's founder, Eugene Schueller, Bettencourt Meyers inherited her wealth following the death of her mother, Liliane Bettencourt, in 2017. Known for her reserved nature, she has focused on philanthropy, particularly in scientific research and arts education. Bettencourt Meyers is also an accomplished author, having written extensively on Greek mythology and Jewish-Christian relations.

Jim Walton, born in 1948 in Newport, Arkansas, is the youngest son of Walmart founder Sam Walton. Walton took over leadership roles within the family business and played a significant part in managing its banking operations through Arvest Bank. While his siblings focused on Walmart, Jim expanded the family’s financial interests, helping to grow Arvest into one of the largest regional banks in the Midwest. He is also active in the Walton Family Foundation, supporting initiatives in education and environmental conservation.

Rob Walton, born in 1944 in Tulsa, Oklahoma, is the eldest son of Sam Walton, the founder of Walmart. After graduating from Columbia Law School, Walton joined Walmart in the 1970s as a corporate lawyer. He became chairman of the board in 1992 following his father's death, overseeing Walmart’s transformation into a global retail giant. Under his leadership, Walmart embraced technology and logistics innovations, strengthening its market dominance. Walton retired as chairman in 2015 but remains deeply involved in philanthropy through the Walton Family Foundation.

Shiv Nadar, born in 1945 in Tamil Nadu, India, is the founder of HCL Technologies, one of India's largest IT services companies. Starting as a hardware company in 1976, HCL evolved into a global software and IT services leader under Nadar’s guidance. Beyond his business achievements, Nadar is a prominent philanthropist, dedicating much of his wealth to education. The Shiv Nadar Foundation has established numerous schools and universities aimed at providing world-class education to underprivileged students in India.

Li Ka-Shing, born in 1928 in Chaozhou, China, fled to Hong Kong during World War II and built one of Asia's largest business empires from scratch. Starting as a plastic manufacturer, Li expanded his business into real estate, telecommunications, and energy. His flagship company, CK Hutchison Holdings, operates in over 50 countries. Li is also known for his philanthropy, having donated billions to healthcare, education, and disaster relief through his charitable foundation.

Masayoshi Son, born in 1957 in Tosu, Japan, is the founder and CEO of SoftBank Group, a global conglomerate with interests in telecommunications, investment, and technology. After graduating from UC Berkeley, Son returned to Japan and established SoftBank in 1981. His bold investments, including early stakes in Yahoo and Alibaba, have made SoftBank one of the most influential players in tech. Despite his high-risk strategy, Son has earned a reputation as a visionary who shapes the future of technology.

Richard Branson, born in 1950 in London, England, is the founder of the Virgin Group, which encompasses over 400 companies in industries ranging from music to space travel. Branson launched his first business, a student magazine, at 16 and later founded Virgin Records, which became a leading music label. His ventures expanded to airlines, fitness, and even commercial space tourism with Virgin Galactic. Known for his adventurous personality and philanthropic efforts, Branson has attempted several world records, including transatlantic balloon crossings.

George Soros, born in 1930 in Budapest, Hungary, survived the Nazi occupation before emigrating to England. He attended the London School of Economics, studying under philosopher Karl Popper, whose ideas influenced Soros’s financial and philanthropic career. After founding Soros Fund Management in 1970, he became one of the most successful investors in history. His Open Society Foundations have donated billions to promote democracy, education, and human rights worldwide, making him one of the most impactful philanthropists of our time.

Andrew Forrest, born in 1961 in Perth, Australia, is the founder and chairman of Fortescue Metals Group, one of the world's largest iron ore producers. Forrest transformed Fortescue into a mining powerhouse by capitalizing on Australia’s vast natural resources. Beyond mining, Forrest is a leading philanthropist, focusing on ending modern slavery, Indigenous education, and environmental conservation through the Minderoo Foundation.

Barbara Cox Anthony, born in 1922 in Dayton, Ohio, was the daughter of James M. Cox, founder of Cox Enterprises, a media conglomerate. After inheriting her father’s wealth, Anthony became a significant shareholder in the company. She focused her efforts on philanthropy, supporting education and animal welfare initiatives. Her legacy continues to impact communities through the Cox Foundation’s various programs.

François Pinault, born in 1936 in Les Champs-Géraux, France, is the founder of Kering, one of the largest luxury goods companies in the world. Starting his career in the timber trade, Pinault transformed his business through strategic acquisitions in the luxury sector, including brands like Gucci, Yves Saint Laurent, and Balenciaga. Known for his business acumen, he also owns the auction house Christie's and has a prominent art collection. Pinault is recognized for his contributions to the arts and is a major figure in the global luxury and cultural industries.

David Tepper, born in 1957 in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, is a billionaire investor and hedge fund manager, known for founding Appaloosa Management. After earning his MBA from Carnegie Mellon University, Tepper began his career at Goldman Sachs before launching his own fund in 1993. His investment philosophy focuses on distressed assets, and he is known for bold, contrarian bets that have often paid off handsomely. Tepper is also the owner of the NFL's Carolina Panthers and a noted philanthropist, donating generously to education and health-related causes.

Dieter Schwarz, born in 1939 in Heilbronn, Germany, is the reclusive founder of the Schwarz Group, the parent company of Lidl and Kaufland. Schwarz took over his father’s grocery business in the 1970s and expanded it into one of the largest retail empires in the world. Known for his frugal lifestyle, Schwarz rarely appears in public or gives interviews. His philanthropic work includes significant donations to education and research in Germany through the Dieter Schwarz Foundation.

Ken Griffin, born in 1968 in Daytona Beach, Florida, is the founder and CEO of Citadel, one of the most successful hedge funds in the world. Griffin started trading stocks while studying at Harvard University and launched Citadel in 1990 with just $4.6 million. Today, the firm manages tens of billions of dollars in assets. Griffin is known for his meticulous approach to risk management and his passion for philanthropy, donating extensively to education, arts, and healthcare.

Jim Simons, born in 1938 in Brookline, Massachusetts, is a mathematician and founder of Renaissance Technologies, a hedge fund known for its use of quantitative models. Simons earned a Ph.D. in mathematics and worked as a codebreaker before applying his skills to finance. His fund’s flagship Medallion Fund is considered one of the most successful in history, consistently generating outsized returns. Simons is also a philanthropist, funding education, research, and autism-related initiatives through his foundation.

Carlos Slim Helú, born in 1940 in Mexico City, is a business magnate and philanthropist. Slim built his fortune through investments in telecommunications, banking, and construction. His company, América Móvil, is the largest telecom operator in Latin America. Known for his strategic acquisitions during economic downturns, Slim has been a prominent figure on the list of the world’s richest people. Through the Carlos Slim Foundation, he has donated billions to health, education, and cultural initiatives.

Jack Ma, born in 1964 in Hangzhou, China, is the founder of Alibaba Group, one of the world’s largest e-commerce and technology companies. A former English teacher, Ma founded Alibaba in 1999 with the goal of helping small businesses compete globally. His charismatic leadership and vision transformed the company into a global powerhouse. Ma stepped down as chairman in 2019 but remains a key figure in China's tech ecosystem. He is also a philanthropist, focusing on education and environmental sustainability.

Steve Ballmer, born in 1956 in Detroit, Michigan, is the former CEO of Microsoft and current owner of the NBA's Los Angeles Clippers. Ballmer joined Microsoft in 1980 as its 30th employee and helped grow the company into a global tech giant. As CEO from 2000 to 2014, he oversaw major product launches and acquisitions. Ballmer's energetic personality and leadership style are well-known, and he has since focused on philanthropy and sports management.

Ingvar Kamprad, born in 1926 in Småland, Sweden, was the founder of IKEA, the world’s largest furniture retailer. Kamprad started IKEA at the age of 17, naming it after his initials and the farm where he grew up. His vision of affordable, flat-pack furniture revolutionized the industry. Kamprad was known for his frugal lifestyle and remained involved with IKEA until his passing in 2018. His legacy lives on through the company’s commitment to sustainability and innovation.

Charles Koch, born in 1935 in Wichita, Kansas, is the chairman and CEO of Koch Industries, one of the largest privately held companies in the United States. Under his leadership, the company expanded from oil refining into chemicals, energy, and consumer products. Koch is a prominent advocate of free-market principles and has donated extensively to academic and policy institutions. Despite controversies surrounding his political activism, Koch’s business success and philanthropy have had a significant impact.

Aliko Dangote, born in 1957 in Kano, Nigeria, is Africa's richest person and the founder of Dangote Group. Starting with a small trading business, Dangote expanded into manufacturing and became a leader in industries like cement, sugar, and flour. Known for his business acumen and strategic investments, Dangote has been instrumental in driving economic growth in Africa. His Dangote Cement is the largest cement producer on the continent. Dangote is also committed to philanthropy, focusing on health and education initiatives through the Aliko Dangote Foundation.

Gina Rinehart, born in 1954 in Perth, Australia, is the chair of Hancock Prospecting, a mining company founded by her father, Lang Hancock. After inheriting a struggling business, Rinehart turned it into one of the most profitable mining enterprises in the world. Her leadership in iron ore mining has made her Australia's richest person. Despite her success, Rinehart has faced legal and family disputes over her wealth. She is also a prominent philanthropist, supporting causes like education, medical research, and rural development.

Susanne Klatten, born in 1962 in Bad Homburg, Germany, is a major shareholder in BMW and the pharmaceutical company Altana. Klatten inherited her wealth from her parents, who played a key role in BMW's success. She is known for her business expertise and hands-on management style, helping Altana become a leader in its field before selling a majority stake. Klatten is also an advocate for sustainability and innovation, investing in green technologies and startups through her private investment firm.

Jorge Paulo Lemann, born in 1939 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, is a co-founder of 3G Capital, a private equity firm known for its investments in global brands like Anheuser-Busch, Burger King, and Kraft Heinz. Lemann started his career in banking and became one of Brazil's most influential businessmen. His strategy of cost-cutting and efficiency has transformed the companies 3G Capital invests in. Lemann is also a philanthropist, focusing on education and entrepreneurship in Brazil through the Lemann Foundation.

Theo Albrecht Jr., born in 1950 in Essen, Germany, inherited his wealth from his father, Theo Albrecht Sr., co-founder of Aldi, a global discount supermarket chain. Albrecht Jr. is known for his low-profile lifestyle and focus on maintaining the success of Aldi's business model, which emphasizes affordability and efficiency. He is also involved in the family's investments in Trader Joe's, an American grocery chain. Despite his immense wealth, Albrecht Jr. rarely appears in public or speaks to the media.

Charlene de Carvalho-Heineken, born in 1954 in Amsterdam, Netherlands, is the heiress to the Heineken beer fortune. After the death of her father, Freddy Heineken, she inherited a controlling stake in the company and became one of the richest people in the Netherlands. Despite her initial reluctance, de Carvalho-Heineken embraced her role and helped expand Heineken into one of the world's largest beer producers. She is also active in philanthropy, supporting cultural and educational initiatives through the Heineken Foundation.

Isabel dos Santos, born in 1973 in Baku, Azerbaijan, is an Angolan businesswoman and Africa's first female billionaire. As the daughter of Angola's former president, José Eduardo dos Santos, she built her wealth through investments in telecommunications, oil, and banking. Despite controversies surrounding the origins of her fortune, dos Santos has played a significant role in promoting entrepreneurship and women's empowerment in Africa. She has also faced legal challenges related to allegations of corruption and financial misconduct.

He Xiangjian, born in 1942 in Shunde, China, is the founder of Midea Group, one of the world's largest appliance manufacturers. Starting with a small workshop in 1968, He transformed Midea into a global leader in household appliances and robotics. He stepped down from an active management role in 2012 but remains influential in the company. He is also known for his philanthropy, supporting education and disaster relief initiatives in China.

Nassef Sawiris, born in 1961 in Cairo, Egypt, is a billionaire businessman and the youngest son of Onsi Sawiris, the founder of the Orascom Group. Nassef oversees Orascom Construction Industries, one of the largest engineering and construction companies in the Middle East and North Africa. He also has investments in global companies like Adidas and OCI NV. Sawiris is known for his strategic thinking and has played a key role in modernizing Egypt's infrastructure. He is also active in philanthropy, focusing on education and social development.

Ray Dalio, born in 1949 in Jackson Heights, New York, is the founder of Bridgewater Associates, the world's largest hedge fund. Dalio started investing at the age of 12 and later studied finance at Long Island University and Harvard Business School. He founded Bridgewater in 1975, focusing on macroeconomic strategies. Known for his principles-based management style, Dalio has written best-selling books on leadership and economics. He is also a philanthropist, supporting causes like education, ocean exploration, and mental health research.

Vagit Alekperov, born in 1950 in Baku, Azerbaijan, is a Russian businessman and the former president of Lukoil, one of the largest oil companies in the world. Alekperov began his career as an oil rig worker and climbed the ranks to become a leader in the energy sector. Under his leadership, Lukoil expanded globally, becoming a key player in the oil and gas industry. Alekperov is also a philanthropist, supporting cultural and educational initiatives in Russia.

Daniel Ek, born in 1983 in Stockholm, Sweden, is the co-founder and CEO of Spotify, the world's leading music streaming platform. Ek started his career in tech at a young age, founding several startups before launching Spotify in 2006. His vision of making music accessible to everyone revolutionized the music industry. Ek is also known for his investments in artificial intelligence and sustainability initiatives, aiming to make a positive impact beyond the tech world.

Laurene Powell Jobs, born in 1963 in West Milford, New Jersey, is the widow of Apple co-founder Steve Jobs and the founder of Emerson Collective, a social impact organization. Powell Jobs focuses on education, immigration reform, and environmental sustainability. She is also a prominent philanthropist, supporting initiatives that address social inequality and climate change. Despite her wealth, she maintains a low profile and focuses on creating long-term impact through her work.

Pony Ma, born in 1971 in Shantou, China, is the founder and CEO of Tencent, one of the world's largest tech companies. Tencent's products, including WeChat and QQ, have transformed communication and entertainment in China. Ma's leadership has made Tencent a global powerhouse in gaming, social media, and fintech. Known for his strategic thinking and innovation, Ma is also involved in philanthropy, focusing on education and healthcare in China.

Christy Walton, born in 1949, is the widow of John Walton, the son of Walmart founder Sam Walton. After her husband's death in 2005, Christy inherited a significant share of the Walmart fortune. She is known for her philanthropic efforts, supporting education, arts, and environmental causes. Despite her immense wealth, Christy leads a relatively private life, focusing on her charitable endeavors.

Hasso Plattner, born in 1944 in Berlin, Germany, is a co-founder of SAP, one of the world's largest enterprise software companies. Plattner played a key role in developing SAP's early products, which revolutionized business operations by providing integrated software solutions. After stepping down as CEO, he remained chairman of the supervisory board and focused on philanthropy, particularly in education and scientific research. Plattner has also funded initiatives in climate change and healthcare.

Leonid Mikhelson, born in 1955 in Kaspiysk, Russia, is the chairman of Novatek, Russia's largest independent natural gas producer. Mikhelson began his career as a civil engineer before rising through the ranks in the energy sector. Under his leadership, Novatek expanded its operations globally, including the development of large-scale LNG projects. Mikhelson is also known for his contributions to the arts, supporting contemporary art exhibitions and cultural initiatives in Russia.

Shari Arison, born in 1957 in New York City, is an Israeli-American businesswoman and philanthropist. She inherited her wealth from her father, Ted Arison, founder of Carnival Cruise Lines. Arison has investments in banking, real estate, and infrastructure, but she is best known for her philanthropic work. Through her organization, Good Deeds Day, she promotes kindness and social responsibility worldwide. Arison is also a strong advocate for environmental sustainability.

Hans Rausing, born in 1926 in Gothenburg, Sweden, was the co-owner of Tetra Pak, a global leader in food packaging. Rausing inherited the business from his father and played a crucial role in its international expansion. Under his leadership, Tetra Pak developed innovative packaging solutions that revolutionized the food and beverage industry. Rausing was also a prominent philanthropist, supporting education and environmental conservation. He passed away in 2019, leaving a lasting legacy.

Rinat Akhmetov, born in 1966 in Donetsk, Ukraine, is the founder of SCM Holdings, a diversified conglomerate with interests in steel, coal, and energy. Akhmetov built his business empire during the post-Soviet privatization period and became Ukraine's richest person. Despite controversies surrounding his rise, Akhmetov has focused on philanthropy, supporting healthcare and humanitarian efforts in Ukraine through his charitable foundation.

Dilip Shanghvi, born in 1955 in Amreli, India, is the founder of Sun Pharmaceutical Industries, one of the largest generic drug manufacturers in the world. Shanghvi started the company in 1983 with a focus on producing psychiatric drugs. Over the years, Sun Pharma expanded globally through strategic acquisitions and innovative research. Shanghvi is known for his modest lifestyle and commitment to improving healthcare access worldwide.

Gautam Thapar, born in 1960 in India, is the former chairman of Avantha Group, a multinational conglomerate with interests in power, paper, and chemicals. Thapar transformed the company by modernizing its operations and expanding its global presence. Despite facing financial challenges in recent years, he remains a prominent figure in India's business landscape. Thapar is also known for his support of education and sustainability initiatives.

Vivek Chaand Sehgal, born in 1957 in Delhi, India, is the co-founder of Motherson Group, a leading automotive parts manufacturer. Starting with a small wire business, Sehgal grew Motherson into a global supplier to the automotive industry, serving clients like Mercedes-Benz and BMW. His leadership and customer-centric approach have been key to the company's success. Sehgal is also involved in philanthropic efforts, focusing on education and community development.

Tatiana Bakalchuk, born in 1975 in Moscow, Russia, is the founder and CEO of Wildberries, the largest online retailer in Russia. Starting her business from her apartment while on maternity leave, Bakalchuk grew Wildberries into a multi-billion-dollar e-commerce platform. Known for her determination and innovation, she has become one of Russia's most prominent female entrepreneurs. Bakalchuk is also an advocate for women in business and technology.

Peter Thiel, born in 1967 in Frankfurt, Germany, is a tech entrepreneur and venture capitalist. Thiel co-founded PayPal, which revolutionized online payments, and later became one of the earliest investors in Facebook. He also founded Palantir Technologies, a data analytics company used by governments and corporations worldwide. Thiel is known for his contrarian thinking and focus on disruptive innovation. He is also a philanthropist, supporting causes like education and technology research.

Stewart Butterfield, born in 1973 in Lund, Canada, is the co-founder and CEO of Slack Technologies, a workplace communication platform. Butterfield initially pursued a career in philosophy before entering the tech world. He also co-founded Flickr, one of the first photo-sharing platforms. Known for his focus on user experience and design, Butterfield has made Slack a global leader in team collaboration tools. He is also involved in philanthropy, supporting education and arts initiatives.

Sara Blakely, born in 1971 in Clearwater, Florida, is the founder of Spanx, a leading shapewear brand. Starting with just $5,000 in savings, Blakely developed her first product and quickly gained recognition for her innovative designs. Spanx became a household name, and Blakely became the youngest self-made female billionaire in the United States. She is also a philanthropist, focusing on empowering women through education and entrepreneurship.

Robert Pera, born in 1978 in San Carlos, California, is the founder and CEO of Ubiquiti Networks, a technology company specializing in wireless communication products. Pera left a promising career at Apple to start his own company, which quickly became a leader in the networking industry. In addition to his business success, Pera owns the NBA's Memphis Grizzlies and is involved in community development projects.

Daniel Zhang, born in 1972 in Shanghai, China, is the CEO of Alibaba Group. Zhang joined Alibaba in 2007 and played a key role in developing its e-commerce platforms. Mikhail Fridman, born in 1964 in Lviv, Ukraine, is the co-founder of Alfa Group, one of Russia's largest privately-owned investment groups. Fridman built his fortune through investments in oil, banking, and telecommunications. Known for his strategic acumen, he has expanded his business interests globally. Fridman is also involved in philanthropy, focusing on education and cultural preservation.

Azim Premji, born in 1945 in Mumbai, India, is the former chairman of Wipro, a multinational IT and consulting company. Under his leadership, Wipro grew from a small family business into a global technology powerhouse. Premji is known for his humility and commitment to giving back, having donated billions through the Azim Premji Foundation to improve education and healthcare in India.

Oleg Deripaska, born in 1968 in Dzerzhinsk, Russia, is a billionaire industrialist and founder of Basic Element, a diversified investment group. Deripaska built his wealth in the aluminum industry, becoming one of the largest producers globally. Despite facing sanctions and controversies, he remains an influential figure in global commodities markets. Deripaska is also involved in philanthropic efforts, focusing on science and education.

Stefan Quandt, born in 1966 in Bad Homburg, Germany, is a major shareholder in BMW and a prominent businessman. As the son of Herbert Quandt, who saved BMW from bankruptcy, Stefan inherited a significant stake in the company. He has focused on maintaining BMW's reputation for quality and innovation. Quandt is also involved in philanthropy, supporting education and environmental initiatives.

Daniel Ek, born in 1983 in Stockholm, Sweden, is the co-founder and CEO of Spotify, the world's leading music streaming platform. Ek started his career in tech at a young age, founding several startups before launching Spotify in 2006. His vision of making music accessible to everyone revolutionized the music industry. Ek is also known for his investments in artificial intelligence and sustainability initiatives.

Joseph Tsai, born in 1964 in Taipei, Taiwan, is the co-founder and executive vice chairman of Alibaba Group. A former lawyer, Tsai played a crucial role in securing funding for Alibaba in its early days. He is also the owner of the Brooklyn Nets NBA team. Tsai is deeply involved in philanthropy, focusing on education, medical research, and social justice initiatives.

Sheryl Sandberg, born in 1969 in Washington, D.C., is the former COO of Meta Platforms and a leading advocate for women in leadership. Sandberg began her career in public policy before joining Google, where she played a key role in its advertising business. She joined Facebook in 2008, helping to transform it into a profitable enterprise. Sandberg is also the author of 'Lean In,' a best-selling book on women and leadership.

Reid Hoffman, born in 1967 in Palo Alto, California, is the co-founder of LinkedIn, the world’s largest professional networking platform. Hoffman began his career in tech at Apple and later joined PayPal before founding LinkedIn in 2002. Under his leadership, LinkedIn revolutionized how professionals connect and advance their careers. Hoffman is also a venture capitalist and philanthropist, supporting innovation and social impact initiatives.
